section.name: CONCEPTS IN NURSING: HEALTHY LIFE STYLES II

comments:
NURS 106 is a course entitled, “Concepts in Nursing: Healthy Lifestyles II.”  The course is designed to expand the students’ knowledge in health promotion and disease prevention.  Students will develop comprehensive assessment skills as well as the ability to define the needs of patients in a family and community context.  The physical assessment of older adults as well as pediatrics will be covered throughout the course as well as the specific assessment of body systems such as the cardiovascular system and the skin.   

Students found the case studies that were incorporated into lectures as helpful and that the lessons covered were relevant to clinical practice.  However, some found the lecture content as “vague.”  Many students reported a discrepancy between the material covered in lectures and the tested material.  Another student added, “The information is at too simple of a level.”  Overall, students’ opinions were mixed on the value of the course material and the clarity of its presentation. 

Students described Professor Quigley as “approachable,” “business-like,” and “one of the best instructors in the Nursing School.”  Students also praised her competency as an instructor in the clinical setting.  Professor Quigley was perceived by the students as “flexible” and “relatable.” 

Because the prerequisites of this course are Nursing intensive, most, if not all, students who take this course are Nursing majors.  NURS 106 is a sophomore-level clinical course offered in the spring as well as the summer.

section.name: CONCEPTS IN NURSING: HEALTHY LIFE STYLES II

comments:
This course focuses on health promotion and disease prevention across the health-illness continuum for healthy and at risk individuals in the community. Students build on their previously mastered communication techniques and clinical skills to develop comprehensive assessment skills and to define needs among specific at risk groups in a family and community context.In weekly seminars, students integrate theories of behavior and health, epidemiologic principles, clinical decision making, and critical thinking skills. Theories are applied utilizing case studies and data sources to develop health promotion and disease prevention strategies. A key component of the course is the development of communication and physical assessment skills and specified clinical techniques. The influence of gender, life span, culture, race, and ethnicity on health promotion and disease prevention is specifically addressed throughout the course. 
Students in the class have various opinions of the lectures. Some students enjoyed the course because of the opportunity to apply knowledge to real clinical applications. They also thought that the case study was helpful in making them understand the materials. The different guest lecturers in the class were a great element and many found them very interesting. However, on the other hand some students thought that clinical experience could have been emphasized even more. Moreover, some thought that the lectures sometimes were not as stimulating and usually go off-topic and as a result they do not feel prepared for next year. 
 Several students thought the course assignments were vague and that more guidelines were needed and expectations could have been made clearer. Other suggestion includes better test preparation.
